Alright, so while there's nothing worse than the zealous fanbase of this game I have to say it is pretty good. Is it the best game ever? Absolutel not. Is it in the top 10 games ever? Not even close. Yet it is still well above average and does many more things well than not. 

What the game does well: Solid coding, it feels very robust and polished with barely any bugs. The storyline and some of the namings are clever. Nothing spectacular bu I appreciate an attempt at an intelligent game. The physics engine is legendary and I have to give credit where credit is due. It does character development well. Oddly enough ti does it much better with all the NPCs than with Gordon. The easter eggs were pretty decent. 

What it does not so well: The storyline is a trifle. It cannot seem to decide whether it wants to be a scientific interdimensional phylosophical mystery, if it wants to be a James bond ripoff, a Resident evil ripoff, or if it wants to be Rambo. In this sense the first installment was leagues better. In the first one Gordon had a hazmat suit which was protecting him from alien energies, which made some sense, while here it somehow is meant to protect him from high caliber bullet rounds primarily. Exceptionally silly. 
The gameplay pace - IF you are going to provide such a revolutionary for its time physics engine, foricng the player to rush through most of the game as bullets rain from every direction is just a missed opportunity. It almost purpusefully prohibits exploration and playing around with the physics in a creative way. 
Gordon is a complete mess of a character. He jumps into the mission because he is called to do so, there's no real sense of direction during the entire thing - he just goes where he is told to go by others. It feels more like you are on a Gordon roller-coaster than playing as a main protagonist. 
The in-your-face physics play is also a bit much. There are "puzzles" and areas which require you to explore how the physis works but it is so ham-fisted that it really put me off. It's like screaming "look at our physics engineeee!!!1!!!!1"

Overall I have no gripes with it. It was more enjoyable than not, but I have to say, if you want an objective experience, play through it, absolutely, but just stay away from the fanboys who make it seem like this is the messiah of all gaming - it is not.

Continuing the gameplay of the original Half Life, albeit a bit less fast-paced, Half Life 2 improves tremendously through it's story. While the original Half Life did have a fantastic story, and was revolutionary for it, it didn't really have any characters aside from the various unnamed scientists and security guards at Black Mesa (GMan too, and I guess Gordon as well). Half Life 2 starts by immediately bringing back the GMan, introducing Dr. Breen and reintroducing Barney (the protagonist of Blue Shift, one of Half Life's expansions). Half Life 2 is a character-driven story, with the struggles of the resistance and its leaders being the true focus, and it excels at this. Alyx is the highlight, I'm a gay man but I'll be damned if she isn't my waifu. Kleiner and Lamarr, Eli and Mossman, even Dr. Breen is likable and he's the fucking antagonist.

Oh and the physics engine is very fun, the Gravity Gun is brilliant and it works beautifully. This is a must-play, but I'll warn you that you may develop a crush on Alyx.

I'm trying to suffer through this game since I've always heard it's a classic, but Jesus Christ I hate it.  The story is nonsensical, the combat is mediocre at best, and I have never hated a group of NPCs so much in my entire life.  If this is what the big to-do is all about, I'm glad HL3 will remain in development oblivion.
